SV Flags

  • svtype

    An enum of flags for Perl types. These are found in the file sv.h in the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    svtype enum. Test these flags with the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvTYPE macro.

    The types are:

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        SVt_NULL
    SVt_IV
    SVt_NV
    SVt_RV
    SVt_PV
    SVt_PVIV
    SVt_PVNV
    SVt_PVMG
    SVt_INVLIST
    SVt_REGEXP
    SVt_PVGV
    SVt_PVLV
    SVt_PVAV
    SVt_PVHV
    SVt_PVCV
    SVt_PVFM
    SVt_PVIO

    These are most easily explained from the bottom up.

    SVt_PVIO is for I/O objects, SVt_PVFM for formats, SVt_PVCV for subroutines, SVt_PVHV for hashes and SVt_PVAV for arrays.

    All the others are scalar types, that is, things that can be bound to a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $ variable. For these, the internal types are mostly orthogonal to types in the Perl language.

    Hence, checking http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvTYPE(sv) < SVt_PVAV is the best way to see whether something is a scalar.

    SVt_PVGV represents a typeglob. If !SvFAKE(sv), then it is a real, incoercible typeglob. If SvFAKE(sv), then it is a scalar to which a typeglob has been assigned. Assigning to it again will stop it from being a typeglob. SVt_PVLV represents a scalar that delegates to another scalar behind the scenes. It is used, e.g., for the return value of substr and for tied hash and array elements. It can hold any scalar value, including a typeglob. SVt_REGEXP is for regular expressions. SVt_INVLIST is for Perl core internal use only.

    SVt_PVMG represents a "normal" scalar (not a typeglob, regular expression, or delegate). Since most scalars do not need all the internal fields of a PVMG, we save memory by allocating smaller structs when possible. All the other types are just simpler forms of SVt_PVMG, with fewer internal fields. SVt_NULL can only hold undef. SVt_IV can hold undef, an integer, or a reference. (SVt_RV is an alias for SVt_IV, which exists for backward compatibility.) SVt_NV can hold any of those or a double. SVt_PV can only hold undef or a string. SVt_PVIV is a superset of SVt_PV and SVt_IV. SVt_PVNV is similar. SVt_PVMG can hold anything SVt_PVNV can hold, but it can, but does not have to, be blessed or magical.

  • SVt_INVLIST

    Type flag for scalars. See svtype.

  • SVt_IV

    Type flag for scalars. See svtype.

  • SVt_NULL

    Type flag for scalars. See svtype.

  • SVt_NV

    Type flag for scalars. See svtype.

  • SVt_PV

    Type flag for scalars. See svtype.

  • SVt_PVAV

    Type flag for arrays. See svtype.

  • SVt_PVCV

    Type flag for subroutines. See svtype.

  • SVt_PVFM

    Type flag for formats. See svtype.

  • SVt_PVGV

    Type flag for typeglobs. See svtype.

  • SVt_PVHV

    Type flag for hashes. See svtype.

  • SVt_PVIO

    Type flag for I/O objects. See svtype.

  • SVt_PVIV

    Type flag for scalars. See svtype.

  • SVt_PVLV

    Type flag for scalars. See svtype.

  • SVt_PVMG

    Type flag for scalars. See svtype.

  • SVt_PVNV

    Type flag for scalars. See svtype.

  • SVt_REGEXP

    Type flag for regular expressions. See svtype.

SV Manipulation Functions

  • boolSV

    Returns a true SV if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    b is a true value, or a false SV if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    b is 0.

    See also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    PL_sv_yes and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    PL_sv_no .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV *	boolSV(bool b)
  • croak_xs_usage

    A specialised variant of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    croak() for emitting the usage message for xsubs

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        croak_xs_usage(cv, "eee_yow");

    works out the package name and subroutine name from http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    cv , and then calls http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    croak() . Hence if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    cv is http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    &ouch::awk , it would call http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    croak as:

    1.     Perl_croak(aTHX_ "Usage: %"SVf"::%"SVf"(%s)", "ouch" "awk", "eee_yow");
    3. 	void	croak_xs_usage(const CV *const cv,
    4. 		               const char *const params)
  • get_sv

    Returns the SV of the specified Perl scalar. http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    flags are passed to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    gv_fetchpv . If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    GV_ADD is set and the Perl variable does not exist then it will be created. If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    flags is zero and the variable does not exist then NULL is returned.

    NOTE: the perl_ form of this function is deprecated.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	get_sv(const char *name, I32 flags)
  • newRV_inc

    Creates an RV wrapper for an SV. The reference count for the original SV is incremented.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	newRV_inc(SV* sv)
  • newSVpadname

    NOTE: this function is experimental and may change or be removed without notice.

    Creates a new SV containing the pad name. This is currently identical to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    newSVsv , but pad names may cease being SVs at some point, so http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    newSVpadname is preferable.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	newSVpadname(PADNAME *pn)
  • newSVpvn_utf8

    Creates a new SV and copies a string into it. If utf8 is true, calls http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvUTF8_on on the new SV. Implemented as a wrapper around http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    newSVpvn_flags .

    1. 	SV*	newSVpvn_utf8(NULLOK const char* s, STRLEN len,
    2. 		              U32 utf8)
  • SvCUR

    Returns the length of the string which is in the SV. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvLEN .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	STRLEN	SvCUR(SV* sv)
  • SvCUR_set

    Set the current length of the string which is in the SV. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvCUR and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvIV_set .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvCUR_set(SV* sv, STRLEN len)
  • SvEND

    Returns a pointer to the spot just after the last character in the string which is in the SV, where there is usually a trailing null (even though Perl scalars do not strictly require it). See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvCUR . Access the character as *(SvEND(sv)).

    Warning: If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvCUR is equal to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvLEN , then http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvEND points to unallocated memory.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	char*	SvEND(SV* sv)
  • SvGAMAGIC

    Returns true if the SV has get magic or overloading. If either is true then the scalar is active data, and has the potential to return a new value every time it is accessed. Hence you must be careful to only read it once per user logical operation and work with that returned value. If neither is true then the scalar's value cannot change unless written to.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	U32	SvGAMAGIC(SV* sv)
  • SvGROW

    Expands the character buffer in the SV so that it has room for the indicated number of bytes (remember to reserve space for an extra trailing NUL character). Calls http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_grow to perform the expansion if necessary. Returns a pointer to the character buffer. SV must be of type >= SVt_PV. One alternative is to call http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_grow if you are not sure of the type of SV.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	char *	SvGROW(SV* sv, STRLEN len)
  • SvIOK

    Returns a U32 value indicating whether the SV contains an integer.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	U32	SvIOK(SV* sv)
  • SvIOKp

    Returns a U32 value indicating whether the SV contains an integer. Checks the private setting. Use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvIOK instead.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	U32	SvIOKp(SV* sv)
  • SvIOK_notUV

  • SvIOK_only

    Tells an SV that it is an integer and disables all other OK bits.

    perltidy

    	void	SvIOK_only(SV* sv)
  • SvIOK_only_UV

    Tells an SV that it is an unsigned integer and disables all other OK bits.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvIOK_only_UV(SV* sv)
  • SvIOK_UV

    Returns a boolean indicating whether the SV contains an integer that must be interpreted as unsigned. A non-negative integer whose value is within the range of both an IV and a UV may be be flagged as either SvUOK or SVIOK.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	bool	SvIOK_UV(SV* sv)
  • SvIsCOW

    Returns a U32 value indicating whether the SV is Copy-On-Write (either shared hash key scalars, or full Copy On Write scalars if 5.9.0 is configured for COW).

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	U32	SvIsCOW(SV* sv)
  • SvIsCOW_shared_hash

    Returns a boolean indicating whether the SV is Copy-On-Write shared hash key scalar.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	bool	SvIsCOW_shared_hash(SV* sv)
  • SvIV

    Coerces the given SV to an integer and returns it. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvIVx for a version which guarantees to evaluate sv only once.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	IV	SvIV(SV* sv)
  • SvIVX

    Returns the raw value in the SV's IV slot, without checks or conversions. Only use when you are sure SvIOK is true. See also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvIV() .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	IV	SvIVX(SV* sv)
  • SvIVx

    Coerces the given SV to an integer and returns it. Guarantees to evaluate http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv only once. Only use this if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv is an expression with side effects, otherwise use the more efficient http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvIV .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	IV	SvIVx(SV* sv)
  • SvIV_nomg

    Like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvIV but doesn't process magic.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

  • SvIV_set

    Set the value of the IV pointer in sv to val. It is possible to perform the same function of this macro with an lvalue assignment to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvIVX . With future Perls, however, it will be more efficient to use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvIV_set instead of the lvalue assignment to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvIVX .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

  • SvLEN

    Returns the size of the string buffer in the SV, not including any part attributable to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

  • SvNV

    Coerce the given SV to a double and return it. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvNVx for a version which guarantees to evaluate sv only once.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	NV	SvNV(SV* sv)
  • SvNVX

    Returns the raw value in the SV's NV slot, without checks or conversions. Only use when you are sure SvNOK is true. See also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvNV() .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	NV	SvNVX(SV* sv)
  • SvNVx

    Coerces the given SV to a double and returns it. Guarantees to evaluate http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv only once. Only use this if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv is an expression with side effects, otherwise use the more efficient http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvNV .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	NV	SvNVx(SV* sv)
  • SvNV_nomg

    Like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvNV but doesn't process magic.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

  • SvNV_set

    Set the value of the NV pointer in sv to val. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

  • SvOK

    Returns a U32 value indicating whether the value is defined. This is only meaningful for scalars.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	U32	SvOK(SV* sv)
  • SvOOK

    Returns a U32 indicating whether the pointer to the string buffer is offset. This hack is used internally to speed up removal of characters from the beginning of a SvPV. When SvOOK is true, then the start of the allocated string buffer is actually http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvOOK_offset() bytes before SvPVX. This offset used to be stored in SvIVX, but is now stored within the spare part of the buffer.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	U32	SvOOK(SV* sv)
  • SvOOK_offset

    Reads into len the offset from SvPVX back to the true start of the allocated buffer, which will be non-zero if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_chop has been used to efficiently remove characters from start of the buffer. Implemented as a macro, which takes the address of len, which must be of type http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    STRLEN . Evaluates sv more than once. Sets len to 0 if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvOOK(sv) is false.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvOOK_offset(NN SV*sv, STRLEN len)
  • SvPOK

    Returns a U32 value indicating whether the SV contains a character string.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	U32	SvPOK(SV* sv)
  • SvPOKp

    Returns a U32 value indicating whether the SV contains a character string. Checks the private setting. Use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPOK instead.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	U32	SvPOKp(SV* sv)
  • SvPOK_off

    Unsets the PV status of an SV.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvPOK_off(SV* sv)
  • SvPOK_on

    Tells an SV that it is a string.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvPOK_on(SV* sv)
  • SvPOK_only

    Tells an SV that it is a string and disables all other OK bits. Will also turn off the UTF-8 status.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvPOK_only(SV* sv)
  • SvPOK_only_UTF8

    Tells an SV that it is a string and disables all other OK bits, and leaves the UTF-8 status as it was.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvPOK_only_UTF8(SV* sv)
  • SvPV

    Returns a pointer to the string in the SV, or a stringified form of the SV if the SV does not contain a string. The SV may cache the stringified version becoming http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPOK . Handles 'get' magic. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    len variable will be set to the length of the string (this is a macro, so don't use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    &len ). See also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPVx for a version which guarantees to evaluate sv only once.

    Note that there is no guarantee that the return value of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPV() is equal to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPVX(sv) , or that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPVX(sv) contains valid data, or that successive calls to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPV(sv) will return the same pointer value each time. This is due to the way that things like overloading and Copy-On-Write are handled. In these cases, the return value may point to a temporary buffer or similar. If you absolutely need the SvPVX field to be valid (for example, if you intend to write to it), then see SvPV_force.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	char*	SvPV(SV* sv, STRLEN len)
  • SvPVbyte

  • SvPVX

    Returns a pointer to the physical string in the SV. The SV must contain a string. Prior to 5.9.3 it is not safe to execute this macro unless the SV's type >= SVt_PV.

    This is also used to store the name of an autoloaded subroutine in an XS AUTOLOAD routine. See Autoloading with XSUBs in perlguts.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	char*	SvPVX(SV* sv)
  • SvPVx

    A version of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPV which guarantees to evaluate http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv only once. Only use this if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv is an expression with side effects, otherwise use the more efficient http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPV .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	char*	SvPVx(SV* sv, STRLEN len)
  • SvPV_force

    Like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPV but will force the SV into containing a string (http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPOK ), and only a string (http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPOK_only ), by hook or by crook. You need force if you are going to update the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPVX directly. Processes get magic.

    Note that coercing an arbitrary scalar into a plain PV will potentially strip useful data from it. For example if the SV was http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvROK , then the referent will have its reference count decremented, and the SV itself may be converted to an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPOK scalar with a string buffer containing a value such as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    "ARRAY(0x1234)" .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	char*	SvPV_force(SV* sv, STRLEN len)
  • SvPV_force_nomg

    Like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

  • SvPV_set

    Set the value of the PV pointer in sv to val. See also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvIV_set .

    Beware that the existing pointer may be involved in copy-on-write or other mischief, so do http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvOOK_off(sv) and use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_force_normal or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPV_force (or check the SvIsCOW flag) first to make sure this modification is safe.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvPV_set(SV* sv, char* val)
  • SvREFCNT

    Returns the value of the object's reference count.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	U32	SvREFCNT(SV* sv)
  • SvREFCNT_dec

    Decrements the reference count of the given SV. sv may be NULL.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvREFCNT_dec(SV* sv)
  • SvREFCNT_dec_NN

    Same as SvREFCNT_dec, but can only be used if you know sv is not NULL. Since we don't have to check the NULLness, it's faster and smaller.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvREFCNT_dec_NN(SV* sv)
  • SvREFCNT_inc

    Increments the reference count of the given SV, returning the SV.

    All of the following SvREFCNT_inc* macros are optimized versions of SvREFCNT_inc, and can be replaced with SvREFCNT_inc.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	SvREFCNT_inc(SV* sv)
  • SvREFCNT_inc_NN

    Same as SvREFCNT_inc, but can only be used if you know sv is not NULL. Since we don't have to check the NULLness, it's faster and smaller.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	SvREFCNT_inc_NN(SV* sv)
  • SvREFCNT_inc_simple

    Same as SvREFCNT_inc, but can only be used with expressions without side effects. Since we don't have to store a temporary value, it's faster.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	SvREFCNT_inc_simple(SV* sv)
  • SvREFCNT_inc_simple_NN

    Same as SvREFCNT_inc_simple, but can only be used if you know sv is not NULL. Since we don't have to check the NULLness, it's faster and smaller.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	SvREFCNT_inc_simple_NN(SV* sv)
  • SvREFCNT_inc_simple_void

    Same as SvREFCNT_inc_simple, but can only be used if you don't need the return value. The macro doesn't need to return a meaningful value.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvREFCNT_inc_simple_void(SV* sv)
  • SvREFCNT_inc_simple_void_NN

    Same as SvREFCNT_inc, but can only be used if you don't need the return value, and you know that sv is not NULL. The macro doesn't need to return a meaningful value, or check for NULLness, so it's smaller and faster.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvREFCNT_inc_simple_void_NN(SV* sv)
  • SvREFCNT_inc_void

    Same as SvREFCNT_inc, but can only be used if you don't need the return value. The macro doesn't need to return a meaningful value.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvREFCNT_inc_void(SV* sv)
  • SvREFCNT_inc_void_NN

    Same as SvREFCNT_inc, but can only be used if you don't need the return value, and you know that sv is not NULL. The macro doesn't need to return a meaningful value, or check for NULLness, so it's smaller and faster.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvREFCNT_inc_void_NN(SV* sv)

  • SvTAINT

    Taints an SV if tainting is enabled, and if some input to the current expression is tainted--usually a variable, but possibly also implicit inputs such as locale settings. http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvTAINT propagates that taintedness to the outputs of an expression in a pessimistic fashion; i.e., without paying attention to precisely which outputs are influenced by which inputs.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvTAINT(SV* sv)
  • SvTAINTED

    Checks to see if an SV is tainted. Returns TRUE if it is, FALSE if not.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	bool	SvTAINTED(SV* sv)
  • SvTAINTED_off

    Untaints an SV. Be very careful with this routine, as it short-circuits some of Perl's fundamental security features. XS module authors should not use this function unless they fully understand all the implications of unconditionally untainting the value. Untainting should be done in the standard perl fashion, via a carefully crafted regexp, rather than directly untainting variables.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvTAINTED_off(SV* sv)
  • SvTAINTED_on

    Marks an SV as tainted if tainting is enabled.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvTAINTED_on(SV* sv)
  • SvTRUE

    Returns a boolean indicating whether Perl would evaluate the SV as true or false. See SvOK() for a defined/undefined test. Handles 'get' magic unless the scalar is already SvPOK, SvIOK or SvNOK (the public, not the private flags).

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	bool	SvTRUE(SV* sv)
  • SvTRUE_nomg

    Returns a boolean indicating whether Perl would evaluate the SV as true or false. See SvOK() for a defined/undefined test. Does not handle 'get' magic.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	bool	SvTRUE_nomg(SV* sv)
  • SvTYPE

    Returns the type of the SV. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    svtype .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	svtype	SvTYPE(SV* sv)
  • SvUOK

    Returns a boolean indicating whether the SV contains an integer that must be interpreted as unsigned. A non-negative integer whose value is within the range of both an IV and a UV may be be flagged as either SvUOK or SVIOK.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	bool	SvUOK(SV* sv)
  • SvUPGRADE

    Used to upgrade an SV to a more complex form. Uses http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_upgrade to perform the upgrade if necessary. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    svtype .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvUPGRADE(SV* sv, svtype type)
  • SvUTF8

    Returns a U32 value indicating the UTF-8 status of an SV. If things are set-up properly, this indicates whether or not the SV contains UTF-8 encoded data. You should use this after a call to SvPV() or one of its variants, in case any call to string overloading updates the internal flag.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	U32	SvUTF8(SV* sv)
  • SvUTF8_off

    Unsets the UTF-8 status of an SV (the data is not changed, just the flag). Do not use frivolously.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvUTF8_off(SV *sv)
  • SvUTF8_on

    Turn on the UTF-8 status of an SV (the data is not changed, just the flag). Do not use frivolously.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	SvUTF8_on(SV *sv)
  • SvUV

    Coerces the given SV to an unsigned integer and returns it. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvUVx for a version which guarantees to evaluate sv only once.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	UV	SvUV(SV* sv)
  • SvUVX

    Returns the raw value in the SV's UV slot, without checks or conversions. Only use when you are sure SvIOK is true. See also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvUV() .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	UV	SvUVX(SV* sv)
  • SvUVx

    Coerces the given SV to an unsigned integer and returns it. Guarantees to evaluate http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv only once. Only use this if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv is an expression with side effects, otherwise use the more efficient http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvUV .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	UV	SvUVx(SV* sv)

  • sv_derived_from_pvn

    Returns a boolean indicating whether the SV is derived from the specified class at the C level. To check derivation at the Perl level, call http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    isa() as a normal Perl method.

    Currently, the only significant value for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

SV-Body Allocation

  • looks_like_number

    Test if the content of an SV looks like a number (or is a number). http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    Inf and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    Infinity are treated as numbers (so will not issue a non-numeric warning), even if your atof() doesn't grok them. Get-magic is ignored.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	I32	looks_like_number(SV *const sv)
  • newRV_noinc

    Creates an RV wrapper for an SV. The reference count for the original SV is not incremented.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	newRV_noinc(SV *const sv)
  • newSV

    Creates a new SV. A non-zero http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    len parameter indicates the number of bytes of preallocated string space the SV should have. An extra byte for a trailing NUL is also reserved. (SvPOK is not set for the SV even if string space is allocated.) The reference count for the new SV is set to 1.

    In 5.9.3, newSV() replaces the older NEWSV() API, and drops the first parameter, x, a debug aid which allowed callers to identify themselves. This aid has been superseded by a new build option, PERL_MEM_LOG (see PERL_MEM_LOG in perlhacktips). The older API is still there for use in XS modules supporting older perls.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	newSV(const STRLEN len)
  • newSVhek

    Creates a new SV from the hash key structure. It will generate scalars that point to the shared string table where possible. Returns a new (undefined) SV if the hek is NULL.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	newSVhek(const HEK *const hek)
  • newSViv

    Creates a new SV and copies an integer into it. The reference count for the SV is set to 1.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	newSViv(const IV i)
  • newSVnv

    Creates a new SV and copies a floating point value into it. The reference count for the SV is set to 1.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	newSVnv(const NV n)
  • newSVpv

    Creates a new SV and copies a string into it. The reference count for the SV is set to 1. If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    len is zero, Perl will compute the length using strlen(). For efficiency, consider using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    newSVpvn instead.

    1. 	SV*	newSVpv(const char *const s, const STRLEN len)
  • newSVpvf

    Creates a new SV and initializes it with the string formatted like sprintf.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	newSVpvf(const char *const pat, ...)
  • newSVpvn

    Creates a new SV and copies a buffer into it, which may contain NUL characters (http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    \0 ) and other binary data. The reference count for the SV is set to 1. Note that if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    len is zero, Perl will create a zero length (Perl) string. You are responsible for ensuring that the source buffer is at least http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    len bytes long. If the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    buffer argument is NULL the new SV will be undefined.

    1. 	SV*	newSVpvn(const char *const s, const STRLEN len)
  • newSVpvn_flags

    Creates a new SV and copies a string into it. The reference count for the SV is set to 1. Note that if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    len is zero, Perl will create a zero length string. You are responsible for ensuring that the source string is at least http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    len bytes long. If the s argument is NULL the new SV will be undefined. Currently the only flag bits accepted are http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SVf_UTF8 and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SVs_TEMP . If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SVs_TEMP is set, then http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_2mortal() is called on the result before returning. If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SVf_UTF8 is set, s is considered to be in UTF-8 and the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SVf_UTF8 flag will be set on the new SV. http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    newSVpvn_utf8() is a convenience wrapper for this function, defined as

    1.     #define newSVpvn_utf8(s, len, u)			\
    2. 	newSVpvn_flags((s), (len), (u) ? SVf_UTF8 : 0)
    4. 	SV*	newSVpvn_flags(const char *const s,
    5. 		               const STRLEN len,
    6. 		               const U32 flags)
  • newSVpvn_share

    Creates a new SV with its SvPVX_const pointing to a shared string in the string table. If the string does not already exist in the table, it is created first. Turns on the SvIsCOW flag (or READONLY and FAKE in 5.16 and earlier). If the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    hash parameter is non-zero, that value is used; otherwise the hash is computed. The string's hash can later be retrieved from the SV with the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvSHARED_HASH() macro. The idea here is that as the string table is used for shared hash keys these strings will have SvPVX_const == HeKEY and hash lookup will avoid string compare.

    1. 	SV*	newSVpvn_share(const char* s, I32 len, U32 hash)
  • newSVpvs

    Like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    1. 	SV*	newSVpvs(const char* s)

    Like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

  • newSVrv

    Creates a new SV for the existing RV, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    rv , to point to. If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    rv is not an RV then it will be upgraded to one. If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    classname is non-null then the new SV will be blessed in the specified package. The new SV is returned and its reference count is 1. The reference count 1 is owned by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    rv .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	newSVrv(SV *const rv,
		        const char *const classname)
  • newSVsv

    perltidy

    sv_setsv .)

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    	SV*	newSVsv(SV *const old)

  • newSV_type

    Creates a new SV, of the type specified. The reference count for the new SV is set to 1.

  • sv_2bool

    This macro is only used by sv_true() or its macro equivalent, and only if the latter's argument is neither SvPOK, SvIOK nor SvNOK. It calls sv_2bool_flags with the SV_GMAGIC flag.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	bool	sv_2bool(SV *const sv)
  • sv_2bool_flags

    This function is only used by sv_true() and friends, and only if the latter's argument is neither SvPOK, SvIOK nor SvNOK. If the flags contain SV_GMAGIC, then it does an mg_get() first.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	bool	sv_2bool_flags(SV *sv, I32 flags)
  • sv_2cv

    Using various gambits, try to get a CV from an SV; in addition, try if possible to set http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    *st and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    *gvp to the stash and GV associated with it. The flags in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    lref are passed to gv_fetchsv.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	CV*	sv_2cv(SV* sv, HV **const st, GV **const gvp,
		       const I32 lref)
  • sv_2io

    Using various gambits, try to get an IO from an SV: the IO slot if its a GV; or the recursive result if we're an RV; or the IO slot of the symbol named after the PV if we're a string.

    'Get' magic is ignored on the sv passed in, but will be called on http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvRV(sv) if sv is an RV.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	IO*	sv_2io(SV *const sv)
  • sv_2iv_flags

    Return the integer value of an SV, doing any necessary string conversion. If flags includes SV_GMAGIC, does an mg_get() first. Normally used via the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvIV(sv) and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvIVx(sv) macros.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	IV	sv_2iv_flags(SV *const sv, const I32 flags)
  • sv_2mortal

    Marks an existing SV as mortal. The SV will be destroyed "soon", either by an explicit call to FREETMPS, or by an implicit call at places such as statement boundaries. SvTEMP() is turned on which means that the SV's string buffer can be "stolen" if this SV is copied. See also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_newmortal and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_mortalcopy .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	sv_2mortal(SV *const sv)
  • sv_2nv_flags

    Return the num value of an SV, doing any necessary string or integer conversion. If flags includes SV_GMAGIC, does an mg_get() first. Normally used via the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvNV(sv) and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

  • sv_2pvbyte

    Return a pointer to the byte-encoded representation of the SV, and set *lp to its length. May cause the SV to be downgraded from UTF-8 as a side-effect.

    Usually accessed via the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

  • sv_2pvutf8

    Return a pointer to the UTF-8-encoded representation of the SV, and set *lp to its length. May cause the SV to be upgraded to UTF-8 as a side-effect.

  • sv_2pv_flags

    Returns a pointer to the string value of an SV, and sets *lp to its length. If flags includes SV_GMAGIC, does an mg_get() first. Coerces sv to a string if necessary. Normally invoked via the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

  • sv_backoff

  • sv_bless

    Blesses an SV into a specified package. The SV must be an RV. The package must be designated by its stash (see http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    gv_stashpv() ). The reference count of the SV is unaffected.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	sv_bless(SV *const sv, HV *const stash)
  • sv_catpv

    Concatenates the string onto the end of the string which is in the SV. If the SV has the UTF-8 status set, then the bytes appended should be valid UTF-8. Handles 'get' magic, but not 'set' magic. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_catpv_mg .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	sv_catpv(SV *const sv, const char* ptr)
  • sv_catpvf

    Processes its arguments like sprintf and appends the formatted output to an SV. If the appended data contains "wide" characters (including, but not limited to, SVs with a UTF-8 PV formatted with %s, and characters >255 formatted with %c), the original SV might get upgraded to UTF-8. Handles 'get' magic, but not 'set' magic. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_catpvf_mg . If the original SV was UTF-8, the pattern should be valid UTF-8; if the original SV was bytes, the pattern should be too.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	sv_catpvf(SV *const sv, const char *const pat,
		          ...)
  • sv_catpvf_mg

    Like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_catpvf , but also handles 'set' magic.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

		             const char *const pat, ...)

    perltidy

    len indicates number of bytes to copy. If the SV has the UTF-8 status set, then the bytes appended should be valid UTF-8. Handles 'get' magic, but not 'set' magic. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    Concatenates the string from SV http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    ssv onto the end of the string in SV http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    dsv . If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    Concatenates the string from SV http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    ssv onto the end of the string in SV http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    perltidy

    dsv . If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    flags include http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

  • sv_chop

    Efficient removal of characters from the beginning of the string buffer. SvPOK(sv), or at least SvPOKp(sv), must be true and the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    ptr must be a pointer to somewhere inside the string buffer. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    ptr becomes the first character of the adjusted string. Uses the "OOK hack". On return, only SvPOK(sv) and SvPOKp(sv) among the OK flags will be true.

    Beware: after this function returns, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    ptr and SvPVX_const(sv) may no longer refer to the same chunk of data.

    The unfortunate similarity of this function's name to that of Perl's chop operator is strictly coincidental. This function works from the left; chop works from the right.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	sv_chop(SV *const sv, const char *const ptr)
  • sv_clear

    Clear an SV: call any destructors, free up any memory used by the body, and free the body itself. The SV's head is not freed, although its type is set to all 1's so that it won't inadvertently be assumed to be live during global destruction etc. This function should only be called when REFCNT is zero. Most of the time you'll want to call http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_free() (or its macro wrapper http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvREFCNT_dec ) instead.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	sv_clear(SV *const orig_sv)
  • sv_cmp

    Compares the strings in two SVs. Returns -1, 0, or 1 indicating whether the string in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv1 is less than, equal to, or greater than the string in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv2 . Is UTF-8 and 'use bytes' aware, handles get magic, and will coerce its args to strings if necessary. See also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_cmp_locale .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	I32	sv_cmp(SV *const sv1, SV *const sv2)
  • sv_cmp_flags

    Compares the strings in two SVs. Returns -1, 0, or 1 indicating whether the string in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv1 is less than, equal to, or greater than the string in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv2 . Is UTF-8 and 'use bytes' aware and will coerce its args to strings if necessary. If the flags include SV_GMAGIC, it handles get magic. See also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

  • sv_collxfrm

    perltidy

  • sv_collxfrm_flags

    Add Collate Transform magic to an SV if it doesn't already have it. If the flags contain SV_GMAGIC, it handles get-magic.

    Any scalar variable may carry PERL_MAGIC_collxfrm magic that contains the scalar data of the variable, but transformed to such a format that a normal memory comparison can be used to compare the data according to the locale settings.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	char*	sv_collxfrm_flags(SV *const sv,
		                  STRLEN *const nxp,
		                  I32 const flags)
  • sv_copypv_flags

    Implementation of sv_copypv and sv_copypv_nomg. Calls get magic iff flags include SV_GMAGIC.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	sv_copypv_flags(SV *const dsv, SV *const ssv,
		                const I32 flags)
  • sv_copypv_nomg

    Like sv_copypv, but doesn't invoke get magic first.

    perltidy

    	void	sv_copypv_nomg(SV *const dsv, SV *const ssv)
  • sv_dec

    Auto-decrement of the value in the SV, doing string to numeric conversion if necessary. Handles 'get' magic and operator overloading.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	sv_dec(SV *const sv)
  • sv_dec_nomg

    Auto-decrement of the value in the SV, doing string to numeric conversion if necessary. Handles operator overloading. Skips handling 'get' magic.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	sv_dec_nomg(SV *const sv)
  • sv_eq

    Returns a boolean indicating whether the strings in the two SVs are identical. Is UTF-8 and 'use bytes' aware, handles get magic, and will coerce its args to strings if necessary.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	I32	sv_eq(SV* sv1, SV* sv2)
  • sv_eq_flags

    Returns a boolean indicating whether the strings in the two SVs are identical. Is UTF-8 and 'use bytes' aware and coerces its args to strings if necessary. If the flags include SV_GMAGIC, it handles get-magic, too.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	I32	sv_eq_flags(SV* sv1, SV* sv2, const U32 flags)
  • sv_force_normal_flags

    Undo various types of fakery on an SV, where fakery means "more than" a string: if the PV is a shared string, make a private copy; if we're a ref, stop refing; if we're a glob, downgrade to an xpvmg; if we're a copy-on-write scalar, this is the on-write time when we do the copy, and is also used locally; if this is a vstring, drop the vstring magic. If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SV_COW_DROP_PV is set then a copy-on-write scalar drops its PV buffer (if any) and becomes SvPOK_off rather than making a copy. (Used where this scalar is about to be set to some other value.) In addition, the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    flags parameter gets passed to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_unref_flags() when unreffing. http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_force_normal calls this function with flags set to 0.

    This function is expected to be used to signal to perl that this SV is about to be written to, and any extra book-keeping needs to be taken care of. Hence, it croaks on read-only values.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	sv_force_normal_flags(SV *const sv,
		                      const U32 flags)
  • sv_free

    Decrement an SV's reference count, and if it drops to zero, call http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_clear to invoke destructors and free up any memory used by the body; finally, deallocate the SV's head itself. Normally called via a wrapper macro http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvREFCNT_dec .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	sv_free(SV *const sv)
  • sv_gets

    Get a line from the filehandle and store it into the SV, optionally appending to the currently-stored string. If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    append is not 0, the line is appended to the SV instead of overwriting it. http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    append should be set to the byte offset that the appended string should start at in the SV (typically, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvCUR(sv) is a suitable choice).

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	char*	sv_gets(SV *const sv, PerlIO *const fp,
		        I32 append)
  • sv_grow

    Expands the character buffer in the SV. If necessary, uses http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_unref and upgrades the SV to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

  • sv_isa

  • sv_isobject

    Returns a boolean indicating whether the SV is an RV pointing to a blessed object. If the SV is not an RV, or if the object is not blessed, then this will return false.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    	int	sv_isobject(SV* sv)
  • sv_len

    Returns the length of the string in the SV. Handles magic and type coercion and sets the UTF8 flag appropriately. See also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvCUR , which gives raw access to the xpv_cur slot.

  • sv_len_utf8

    Returns the number of characters in the string in an SV, counting wide UTF-8 bytes as a single character. Handles magic and type coercion.

  • sv_magic

    Adds magic to an SV. First upgrades http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv to type http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SVt_PVMG if necessary, then adds a new magic item of type http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    how to the head of the magic list.

    See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_magicext (which http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_magic now calls) for a description of the handling of the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    name and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    namlen arguments.

    You need to use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_magicext to add magic to SvREADONLY SVs and also to add more than one instance of the same 'how'.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	sv_magic(SV *const sv, SV *const obj,
		         const int how, const char *const name,
		         const I32 namlen)
  • sv_magicext

    Adds magic to an SV, upgrading it if necessary. Applies the supplied vtable and returns a pointer to the magic added.

    Note that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_magicext will allow things that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_magic will not. In particular, you can add magic to SvREADONLY SVs, and add more than one instance of the same 'how'.

    If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    namlen is greater than zero then a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    savepvn copy of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    name is stored, if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    namlen is zero then http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    name is stored as-is and - as another special case - if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    (name && namlen == HEf_SVKEY) then http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    name is assumed to contain an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SV* and is stored as-is with its REFCNT incremented.

    (This is now used as a subroutine by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_magic .)

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	MAGIC *	sv_magicext(SV *const sv, SV *const obj,
		            const int how,
		            const MGVTBL *const vtbl,
		            const char *const name,
		            const I32 namlen)
  • sv_mortalcopy

    Creates a new SV which is a copy of the original SV (using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_setsv ). The new SV is marked as mortal. It will be destroyed "soon", either by an explicit call to FREETMPS, or by an implicit call at places such as statement boundaries. See also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_newmortal and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_2mortal .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	sv_mortalcopy(SV *const oldsv)
  • sv_newmortal

    Creates a new null SV which is mortal. The reference count of the SV is set to 1. It will be destroyed "soon", either by an explicit call to FREETMPS, or by an implicit call at places such as statement boundaries. See also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_mortalcopy and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_2mortal .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    	SV*	sv_newmortal()

  • sv_pos_u2b

    Converts the value pointed to by offsetp from a count of UTF-8 chars from the start of the string, to a count of the equivalent number of bytes; if lenp is non-zero, it does the same to lenp, but this time starting from the offset, rather than from the start of the string. Handles magic and type coercion.

    Use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_pos_u2b_flags in preference, which correctly handles strings longer than 2Gb.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

		           I32 *const lenp)
  • sv_pos_u2b_flags

    Converts the offset from a count of UTF-8 chars from the start of the string, to a count of the equivalent number of bytes; if lenp is non-zero, it does the same to lenp, but this time starting from the offset, rather than from the start of the string.     perltidy

  • sv_reftype

  • sv_replace

    Make the first argument a copy of the second, then delete the original. The target SV physically takes over ownership of the body of the source SV and inherits its flags; however, the target keeps any magic it owns, and any magic in the source is discarded. Note that this is a rather specialist SV copying operation; most of the time you'll want to use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_setsv or one of its many macro front-ends.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	sv_replace(SV *const sv, SV *const nsv)
  • sv_reset

    Underlying implementation for the reset Perl function. Note that the perl-level function is vaguely deprecated.

    1. 	void	sv_reset(const char* s, HV *const stash)
  • sv_rvweaken

    Weaken a reference: set the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvWEAKREF flag on this RV; give the referred-to SV http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    PERL_MAGIC_backref magic if it hasn't already; and push a back-reference to this RV onto the array of backreferences associated with that magic. If the RV is magical, set magic will be called after the RV is cleared.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	sv_rvweaken(SV *const sv)
  • sv_setiv

    perltidy

    sv_setiv , but also handles 'set' magic.

  • sv_setnv

    Copies a double into the given SV, upgrading first if necessary. Does not handle 'set' magic. See also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_setnv_mg .

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	void	sv_setnv(SV *const sv, const NV num)

    perltidy

    perltidy

  • sv_setref_iv

    Copies an integer into a new SV, optionally blessing the SV. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    rv argument will be upgraded to an RV. That RV will be modified to point to the new SV. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    classname argument indicates the package for the blessing. Set http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    classname to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    NULL to avoid the blessing. The new SV will have a reference count of 1, and the RV will be returned.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	sv_setref_iv(SV *const rv,
		             const char *const classname,

  • sv_setref_nv

  • sv_setref_pv

    Copies a pointer into a new SV, optionally blessing the SV. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    rv argument will be upgraded to an RV. That RV will be modified to point to the new SV. If the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    pv argument is NULL then http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    PL_sv_undef will be placed into the SV. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    classname argument indicates the package for the blessing. Set http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    classname to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    NULL to avoid the blessing. The new SV will have a reference count of 1, and the RV will be returned.

    Do not use with other Perl types such as HV, AV, SV, CV, because those objects will become corrupted by the pointer copy process.

    Note that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_setref_pvn copies the string while this copies the pointer.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	sv_setref_pv(SV *const rv,
		             const char *const classname,
		             void *const pv)
  • sv_setref_pvn

    Copies a string into a new SV, optionally blessing the SV. The length of the string must be specified with http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    n . The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    rv argument will be upgraded to an RV. That RV will be modified to point to the new SV. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    classname argument indicates the package for the blessing. Set http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    classname to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    NULL to avoid the blessing. The new SV will have a reference count of 1, and the RV will be returned.

    Note that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    sv_setref_pv copies the pointer while this copies the string.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    	SV*	sv_setref_pvn(SV *const rv,
		              const char *const classname,
		              const char *const pv,
		              const STRLEN n)
